channel.title: Scratch Server
channel.description:
It's very ambitious of me, and I am a still just a learner, but I've decided to have a crack at writing from reference (not copy and paste) a "server" from scratch. I say a "server", I mean something basic, as more of a learning curve. Not to development something amazing as I wouldn't be capable, but just the essentials needed to log in and walk around. What I would like to know is where should I start? What should be added and in what order to do it in? Here's what I got in mind:
*Logging in *Player rendering *Interfaces *Clicking buttons *Frames *Disconnecting *Player saving *Player loading Then: -Items *Inventory *Ground *Equipping *Stacking *Banking *Write bonuses *Item on item *Item on ground item *Item on NPC *Item on player *Item on object -NPCs *Rendering? *Animation *Player versus NPC *Damage calculation -Objects *Loading *Interaction Then: *Clipping (player and NPC)
Thanks for reading.

item.title: Scratch Server
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“Aftermath, post:6, topic:368761”]For connection handling part just look up ServerSocket, Socket, and input/output streams from sockets.

Basically, ServerSocket listens for connections and accepts connections which are represented by Sockets. Sockets have input and output streams. You can send things to clients with output streams and read things with input streams.

For figuring out what packets do what, I suggest you just check out a source with more features and just grab the packet IDs and information about how to read them.

When he says networking he probably means whether you use the java.io or java.nio packages. You should probably be using java.io if you’re just starting out since it’s easier to use. Look up whatever you want on www.exampledepot.com[/quote]

Yeah, I read something about listening for connections earlier on. I will have to refer back to it. This is a good explanation though, I get how it works.

I’ve seen java.io and IOThreads(?) a lot but not really understood the whole IO part. Sounds important. Obviously stands for input/output right? I’m learning something.

[quote=“I Vain I”]Study Grahams, or Blakeman’s releases.

They are basic frameworks.

Hard to program, but it should give you a feel on what you need to do.[/quote]

Yeah I have something of Grahams on my hard drive, but not really understood it.

I’m really intrigued by it all, IO, ServerSockets, masks, packets etc. I’ve read and hoarded a whole heap of documents on my hard drive but not quite comprehended any of it. I know it’s not hard to learn after a while, my life’s just been unsettled recently. I’m trying to absorb as much information as I can and I seem to just take in a bit of everything and not enough of something. That’s why I asked about it, finally.

Your replies are appreciated.

item.title: Scratch Server
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“Primadude, post:3, topic:368761”]I think you should make your server allow connections from a client… that’s not even on the list.

I believe you should re-think your strategy.[/quote]

The list is just my knowledge of what I thought should be. I did not anticipate client connections. I will have to re-think my strategy lol.

[quote=“Aftermath, post:4, topic:368761”]First, you need the actual server component that handles connections.

Then, you need to figure out what data sent means what when sent between client/server.

Then you just need to send the appropriate things to the client and understand what the client is trying to say and handle it.

Player saving / loading can be done by just printing to a file, or with serialization (look up Serializable and serialization in Java).

Anyway, in a rough order:

  1. Server component (handles connection)
  2. Some sort of packet handler that can just read the packets for now, doesn’t have to actually do anything with them
  3. Have your server send the initialization code to each client as it connects and add a case in the packet handler for logging in, work on displaying the player here

Practically everything else from here in terms of functionality (item on item, item on player, etc…) is just handling and sending the correct packets.

After you’ve done all that stuff, you can add in features like saving player data and combat and whatever.

I think you should make your server allow connections from a client… that’s not even on the list.

I believe you should re-think your strategy.

^ this[/quote]

This is helpful. I will now do more browsing and analysing on what you have just said. Do you reccommend studying Winterlove, as it’s a basic source? I’m not looking at ultimate optimisation at first, I can do this once I know the basics of how a server is made.

[quote=“I Vain I”]First, decide which protocol you would like to base your server off of.
Then decide which type of networking you are going to use.
Then write the framework, which should consist of packets, rendering, and update blocks. etc.[/quote]

I would like to use the 317/377 protocol, as I am more familiar with this. Networking… is that sockets? I will have to study this before having a go. Framework also.

This has been helpful to me, guys. I know now what I’ve got ahead of me (more than I anticipated) I’m not saying I will create a successful server, because I won’t, but it’s a start and we all have to start somewhere.

Much obliged.
